DIV1.P: THE ELECTION. A COMEDY OF Three ACTS. As it is now acting in London with great Applause.
LONDON: Printed in the Year MDCCXLIX.

SP.P: MR. Leatherhead, this is a strange Commotion has happen'd of late in your little Community; that Poppets; (who have been hitherto a peaceable Generation,) should all of a sudden, fall a tilting their brainless Heads at each other, to the utter Destruction of all brotherly Affection, is, I must confess very amazing. Pray Heaven at prove no ill Portent to our greater State; I assure you, I cannot but apprehend it extremely.

Ah! Neighbour, the wisest among us are Strangers to what an after-Day may produce. I myself as little apprehended this Rupture, as any Body; but the Truth is, being oblig'd some time ago to make a Reform in my little Commonwealth, there being few of the old Members, who had not by frequent Scuffles, lost some a Nose, others a Leg, and others an Arm, I sent over to Ire∣land, for some of the best Wood that Coun∣try affords, in order to repair the Generations among which Stuff, there happen'd to be one damn'd knotty Log, from the County of The County where Firebrand was born. Clare, who no sooner receiv'd human Form from the Artist's Chissel, than he began to discover some of that perverse cross-grain'd Disposition he was made of. For taking the Advantage, from a late Play I exhibited, call'd, Whittington and his Cat; or, the lucky Venture, He found Means to set the Commons (of which Number he was one) against their good old Friends, the Lord Mayor and Aldermen; by slyly insinuating, as if these latter in their late quarterly Feasts, had depriv'd them of their usual Share of Custard, which As∣sertion the Commons greedily swallowing, have conceiv'd an unconquerable hatred to the Alder∣men, insomuch, that instead of making use of loyal Toasts, as they were us'd to do, at their merry
Meetings, they do nothing but drink Confusion to one another. In short the Breach is made so wide by Means of this Incendiary, that if some Means be not suddenly taken to close it, I am a∣fraid it will be the utter Dissolution of the Society.

This is Strange indeed! that from one Block, should grow so much Confusion. But how happens it, Mr. Leatherhead, that your Night's En∣tertainment is call'd the Election? I can't see, what Reference these Broils have to such a Title.

You shall hear. — You must know, in the midst of these Squabbles, it happen'd, that the Lord Mayor's High Steward, or Keeper of the Key of the Panty, was made away with. For he being disrob'd of his old Cloaths, in order for a fresh Suit, was seiz'd, as he lay in a Corner, by my Cookmaid; who mistaking him for a Log of the old Party, took him to boil the Pot. Now, Sir, as the Vacancy occasion'd by this Accident cannot be fill'd, but by one duly elected to the Office, there have started up, four or five Candi∣dates, in the foremost of whom stands Firebrand, (the Poppet I just now mention'd,) and who is so call'd, from his being of a very hot Constituti∣on, and apt to swell, at the least mention of ar∣bitrary Power, and high Feeding. Now the Al∣dermen, being afraid that if this Poppet carries the Election, nothing but starving on their Side will ensue, use all their Interest to oppose him, while
he, on the other Hand, by cajoling the Commons, with large Promises of what he'll do for them, when he comes to be elected, has drawn them over to his Party. This, Sir, is the present Pos∣ture of Affairs, the Consequence of which this Night's Entertainment must determine.
Well, it must needs afford an abundance of Humour, if it be carry'd on, with the usual Heat attending Elections. — But pray, what part do you intend to take in these Commotions?

None, Sir, none. — I intend to stand Neuter to Night, and leave all their Affairs to their own Management: But see! the People begin to thicken, and 'tis Time we were begun. — Call forth Cheshire Tom there, till he speaks the Prologue. — Here Tom! — Cheshire Tom, hoa! —

DIV2.HEAD: The PROLOGUE.
DIV2.L: LADIES, and Gentlemen, you're welcome here,
And to your Hopes I wish an equal Cheer.
Be not surpriz'd, if we, who once were known
To utter Nonsence in a squeaking Tone,
Whose grimace, Gesture, and unmeaning Noise,
Were thought but fit to tickle Girls and Boys;
Shou'd by attempting now a loftier Stile,
Please Men of Taste, and force the Grave to smile.
For since the greater Stage has thought it fit,
To change, for our low Scenes, their former Wit,
Be far from us th' injurious Charge of Theft,
Since we but take the Things themselves have left.
If dancing, singing, and low mimickry,
Can please your Tastes; pray how much worse are we?
We have our Harlequins, things of mere Wood,
Shall leap you higher than e'er WOODWARD cou'd;
Our Dancers are our own, not purchas'd O're,
At huge Expences, from a foreign Shore:
Yet even these, we'll sacrifice to Night,
To give you a more rational Delight,
To make you at just Wit and Humour smile,
Things long neglected in this wretched Isle.
True Friends of Humour! be it then your part,
Here to applaud and justify our Art;
It matters not, if natural the Joke,
Whether by Players or by Poppets spoke.
Wit still is Wit. — Yet some choice Sparks there are,
Who think such Actors must good Sense im∣pair,
And yet can any Thing from Players bear.
To such we say — we can no Method find
To hit their Tastes, — the Fault is in their Mind.
Let it suffice, that all who see our Play,
Must own we're mended much of our old way;
In doing which we have perform'd our due,
That we proceed, must now depend on you▪
Cheer'd with your Smiles, we'll still more perfect grow,
And Morals spring, e'en from a Poppet-shew,

DIV3.HEAD: The SCENE a great Hall, Whittington and the Aldermen are discovered sitting with Bottles of Wine before them, as at the End of a great Feast.

SP.L: SINCE now, my Friends! our day's Re∣past is o'er,
And we are free to speak, as heretofore;
Since our fat Bellies are with Capon lin'd,
And nought remains, but Business, now to mind:
Let's to the Point, and some sure Method chuse,
How we may baffle Firebrand's haughty Views.
With more Success than cou'd his Hopes insure,
He still goes on new Forces to procure.
The Commons, Rebels to our juster Rule,
Follow in droves the rash hot-headed Fool.
Even our Wives, and Daughters 'gainst us turn;
So much for Oddities do Women burn!
So many Accidents set us upon,
How we may traverse his Election.
For if by any Chance he wins the Day,
He'll take our Custard, and our Rights away.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.L: O 'tis a Wretch, who, to promote his Ends,
Cares not what Strife he causes 'mongst his Friends!
And whate'er Shew of Liberty he makes,
I know, his Teeth but water at our Cakes.
Our Custards, Jellies, and our Sweetmeats rare,
Are Things he can't with any Patience bear:
Might he, with us, have leave on these to fall,
His meagre Chops wou'd soon forget to bawl.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Ald.
SP.L: If then, so small a Thing his Guts do lack,
What hinders, but we stuff them till they crack?
'Twill be cheap Purchase, his good Word to buy,
With the stale Fragments of a Christmas Pye.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.L: You're much mistaken, Friends, if thus you think
To stop this Fellow's Mouth with Meat and Drink.
Mean as the Caitiff is, he does aspire,
So great's his Arrogance, to something higher;
For t'other Day, even in this very Hall,
He whisper'd me, and bid me tell you all;
That Mayor and Aldermen, were Titles which
Did much his Fancy with their Sound bewitch,
And if t' admit him, you wou'd condescend,
He'd be, your ever constant, faithful Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Ald.
SP.L: Perish the Thought! and with it Titles too,
E'er we so base, so mean an Action do:
Shall we exalt from his own native Dung
The Wretch, who has such Slanders at us flung?
Load him with Honours, Titles, and with Place,
Whose Study 'tis, to load us with disgrace?
So shall each noisy Vagrant in the Town,
By Railing hope, to gain a Scarlet Gown.
But if, by my Advice you wou'd be rul'd,
I'd have his Courage by a Whipping cool'd;
And let Jack Ketch, by tawing of his Hide,
This long Dispute 'twixt him and us decide.
I like this Counsel much, that comes from you,
It suits at once, with Wrath and Justice too:
Then let the Hangman wait our strict Commands,
That he may take the Order from our Hands.
But hist!—Here's Firebrand,—Be not, Friends, dismay'd,
Nor fear,—'Till first you see that I'm afraid.

DIV3.STAGE: Firebrand enters at the Head of the Commons, at the Sight of whom the Lord Mayor falls a tremb∣ling, and the Aldermen after him.

SP.L: Well may you tremble, Slaves! and knock each Knee,
When you myself, and injur'd Brethren see.
Those meagre Looks which all our Wants proclaim,
Are but the Marks of what shou'd be your Shame.
Well may we stalk, like Sprites about the Town,
When your vile Feasting keeps our Bellies down;
For, had each starved Citizen his Due,
He'd look as rosey, and as plump as you;
But while like Beasts, you batten here alone,
You both consume our Pasture, and your own.
Peace! Peace! my Friend, and do not be so hot,
Your Hunger, and your Rage we value not,
The Law but gives us, what we well deserve,
We feast by Charter, while by Rules you starve.
O worse than Cannibals! voracious Elves!
Whose only Care is for your worthless selves;
What Law so cruel, to deprive of Meat,
Those loyal Subjects who have Teeth to eat?
But the Truth is, so costly's grown your Food,
You think such Viands are for us too good.
The simplest Cates, were those which most did please
The frugal Aldermen, of former Days;
Ale all their Drink, they Strangers were to Wine,
And thought it Luxury on Beef to dine:
But now their Sons, a gormandizing Crew!
Must have their Puddings, and those spiced too,
Their Pies, their Cram-foul, and such dainty Things,
As are but fitting for the Mouths of Kings.
CUSTARD! a Food, as lawless, as 'tis vain,
Came not in Use till Arthur's glutton Reign,
When being invited to that Monarch's Feast,
You learn'd the courtly Vice of raising Paste.
Since which, each Alderman a Belly bears
Round as a Tun, and mighty as the Spheres.
But Dogs! I'll make you instantly reform,
Or I'll at once, your Guts, and Custard storm.
O Horror! Horror! not to be withstood,
Was e'er such Blasphemy, to rail at Food,
Which all past Ages have esteem'd as good?
By which 'tis plain, this curst malicious Elf
Wou'd have us all, as puny as himself.
Ah! what avails it, to be rich or great,
If Men must not have Liberty to eat?
Better it were, an it were Fortune's Will,
My Cat had stay'd, and I a Scullion still!
My Hunger then, I shou'd have eas'd at least,
Sure of a full, though a less noble, Feast.
But now are Titles empty Names indeed,
When they deprive us of the Means to feed!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.L: O Noble Firebrand! your Rage forbear,
And let his Grief extract from you a Tear;
You see, how heavily the good Man takes
The Loss of all his Custards, Pies and Cakes:
To our fall'n State, do then some Pity shew,
Nor plunge us with thy Strife to farther Woe.
Talk'st thou to me of Pity? Slaves! be∣gone!
Least, in my Rage, I slay you ev'ry one.
Can you expect, I'll at their Sorrows melt,
Who' ne'er themselves one Touch of Pity felt?
As well you may the raging Seas implore,
Or bid the Winds, when loudest, cease to roar;
For by those Gods! who in the Skies exist,
I never will from lashing you desist,
Till I've reduc'd your Bodies, plump and round,
As small as Candles, twenty to the Pound.
Nay, when you're dead, my Rage, ye guilty Slaves!
Shall still pursue, and tear you from your Graves,
And hang you up, (like Felons) for your Crimes,
To be the Scorn and Gaze of future Times!
So hence, ye Slaves! and batten while you may,
The Time's at Hand, you'll for your Junkets pay.

DIV3.STAGE: The Lord Mayor and Aldermen go off trembling.

SP.P:
Well Gentlemen! I hope you will not say, I am Mealy-mouthed in your Cause, or any way shame-faced in defending your Liberties; you see the Rogues begin to be afraid of us already, and I promise, if you will stand by me, to the End of the Chapter, that we will reduce them to their pri∣mitive Condition of Scullion-Boys. For my part, Gentlemen, I can only say, that this poor Carcase of mine, is so much at your Service, that there is no Danger I would not gladly encounter, to rescue
you from your manifold Oppressions, and that with no other Regard to my own Interest, than the bare Satisfaction of having served so worthy a Body of Citizens, of whom I have the Honour to be a Mem∣ber. For why should I covet Bribes, whom ye all know to be contented with a little? or desire Ho∣nours, (being naturally a Man of the greatest Hu∣mility,) if it was not out of a pure Zeal of serving you, my Brethren!—No, No,—This all your Enemies, and mine, are well assured of. 'Tis this, makes them use all their Efforts, to oppose my be∣ing elected to that Honourable Office, which your Love designs me.— But I despise their puny Malice, while supported by you.—And that you may not think my Abilities are unequal to so great a Trust, I will now give you a Sketch of them in the follow∣ing Oration.— Hem! Hem! Hem!
Hear him! Hear him! Hear him!
Gentlemen, Brethren, and Fellow-Citizens,

The End of all Governments, I take it (as Aris∣totle very wisely observes) depends (take Notice, I begin low, that I may rise in a proper Place, ac∣cording to the Method of Demosthenes) depends, I say, upon a certain Concatenation, Assimilation, or Aggregation of the several Parts, which being cemented, ligamented, or rather structerify'd, by the Adhesion, Cooperation, or similar Formation,
of the volitary, circumambient, fluctuating, Va∣gue, and irresidentary Particles; come at length to form, what in the strict Acceptation of the Word, may be termed either monarchical, aristocratical, or democratical, according to the several Usages, Customs, Humours, Habits, Views, political and religious Ordinations, Regulations, Institutions, Agreements, both publick and private, of the se∣veral Countries, wherein such Laws, Pandects, Councils, Statutes, Edicts, Rules, Acts, Orders, Decrees and Injunctions, are divulged, proclaimed, made known, or promulgated, from which no Member can possibly be torn, separated, rent, cashiered, disbanded, but the interiour, or more inward Parts receive a Contusion, Bump, Bruise, Pressure, Scratch, Scarification or Tumour, which is equal, similar, or Corresponsive, to that which occasions what is called the Hystericks, Fits, Maw-Worms, and Mulligrubs, in the Bowels of old aged Men, or young sucking Children, which Observa∣tion may be still strengthened, fortifyed, and cor∣roborated, by a Quotation from the Greek, of that most excellent Historian, and Politician, Paracel∣sus, where he says, in the fifth Chapter of his Book, de modo gubernandi Antiquorum. — Hei mihi, non habeo obolum in marsupio. As also, in that famous Italian Antiquary, Helvidius Priscus, the Son of a worthy Roman Knight, where talking of the Egyptian Coins, he says, (and indeed very much to
the purpose) Non omnia possumus omnes. By which it is evident, that to preserve one's Constitution long, they should live temperate. But why should I dwell upon these Matters to you, Gentlemen? to whose Penetration, no Doubt they are as clear as the Sun at Noon-day? let it suffice to tell you, that so long as these wicked Aldermen have the Fingering of that Money, whose better part ought to be yours, there will be no End of their Usurpations.

O Gentlemen! Gentlemen! was it consistent, either with my known Modesty or Moderation, to enumerate to you their many base Insults, Abuses, Wrongs, and Oppressions, the bare Recital of them would exasperate you to a Degree of Madness; for my part I never think of them that my Wits do not that Moment utterly forsake me, as I feel, they are now a-doing at this present Speaking.—Ha! what's the Matter with my Brain?—turned topsy turvy!—Hey a-day! hey a-day! hey a-day! —Rat-ta-tat,—rat-ta-tat,—rat-ta-tat,—Hur∣ley-burley! Helter-skelter, much-ado about nothing! —The Devil upon two Sticks,—Liberty, Pro∣perty, Arbitrary-power, Popery, Slavery, Cor∣ruption, Fraud, Bribery, Oppression, Tyranny, Force, Violence, Usurpation, Damnation, Devas∣tation, Beggary, Ruin, Destruction, Fire, Sword, Famine, Pestilence, Rebellion, Pretender, Jaco∣bites, Tories, Jesuits, Priests, Judges, Bishops, false Brethren, Aldermen, Knaves, Traitors, Ty∣rants,
Rogues, Villians, Dogs, Thieves, Scoun∣drels.—Stay! stay a Minute Gentlemen, 'till I take Breath a little, and you shall have more of them.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Tr.
SP.P: O Heavens! what a Number of hard Words he has!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d,
SP.P: And with what Ease he delivers them!

SP.SPEAKER: 3d,
SP.P: Well he's certainly a great Man!

SP.SPEAKER: 4th,
SP.P: A most excellent Orator!

SP.SPEAKER: 5th,
SP.P: A charming Scholar!

SP.SPEAKER: 6th,
SP.P: And a fine Politician!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st,
SP.P: Did you observe how fast he spoke Latin?

SP.SPEAKER: 2d,
SP.P: Aye and Greek too, I know it by the Sound.

SP.SPEAKER: 7th,
SP.P: Many a Man has been made a Doctor with less Learning.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st,
SP.P: Aye a Bishop.

SP.SPEAKER: 8th,
SP.P: Our Cause is happy in having such a Defender.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th,
SP.P: Pray God, he may carry the Election.

SP.SPEAKER: 5th,
SP.P: Amen, with all my Heart.—But see, he has now recovered himself and begins to speak again.

Well, Gentlemen, I believe it will be needless to trouble you any farther with my Speech∣ing, 'tis indeed a rough Home-spun Dialect, and by no Means equal to what the Merits of your Cause require, however your Good-nature will make Amends for my Defects, and overlook those
Mistakes, which a sincere Love, and hearty Zeal for your Cause, may possibly lead me into; and be∣cause you have all hitherto expressed a Regard for my particular Welfare, I will now give you an Opportunity of testifying it, by demanding your Votes for the ensuing Election, singularly; and first, Mr. Taylor, I demand Yours.

Faith,—Sir! I am sorry to say,—that not∣withstanding the great Regard I have for your Parts, 'tis not in my Power to give it you, for you must know, my Lord Bustle sent me his new Coat Yes∣terday to alter, with a Note pinned to the Sleeve of it, wherein he orders, that in all Matters rela∣ting to this Election, I should cut out my Measures according to his Pattern.

Flat Bribery and Corruption, by the L—d! take Notice, Sirrah, I will have you and your Lord, to answer this at the next Sitting of the great Coun∣cil.—Here's a Rogue for you!—suffer himself to be influenced!—But what says the Peruke-Maker.

Why, I say Sir, that 'tis a great Grief to me, that I cannot let my Vote go along with my Inclinations, for as I am a young Beginner, and have not many Customers, all my Hair will rot up∣on my Hands, unless I go according to the Instruc∣tions of 'Squire Pigtail.

May your Hair and you rot together, for a corrupt Rascal! for I promise, the City will ne∣ver be a Hair the honester for you.—These are fine Fellows indeed to support a City's Liberties!— But what says the Butcher.

Why as to my Part, look ye, Sir, I defy Mankind to say, I am under the Influence of any Body. I detest such Baseness from my Heart, and think the Man who would be guilty of such a Thing, has no more Honour in him than an Ox; for which Reason I resolve to keep neuter, and vote only for him, who buys most Mutton.
O tempora! O mores! What Sentiments here are! — Why you Calf, more stupid than that you kill, don't you know, that if you sell your Meat on any such Condition, that 'tis still Corrup∣tion?
No, not if he gives me a good Price for it, because, in such a Case I cheat him, when he thought to come round me, and 'tis bite the biter.
Well, thy Stupidity will always be an Excuse for thy Knavery. — But what says the Weaver.

Why indeed, Sir, there is no Man has a warmer Zeal for his friend's Interest than I have; but the Truth is, the Times past have been so hard, and 'tis so long since I made a good Meal, that I am afraid I must be forc'd to vote for him
who Feasts best, if it be only to repair the breaches of the late Famine.

May your Belly grow as small as your Conscience, you slim-gutted Dog! — and may you never eat any thing, but what you get at Elec∣tions — Zounds! the Universality of this Corrup∣tion, almost makes me mad. — Well, I'll try one more before I despair utterly, and that shall be the Carpenter. — His honest, plain Looks shew him to be of a Leaven quite different from these Dogs here, one who will dare be honest even in the worst of Times; such a Person's Vote does Honour to the Man 'tis given to, and if I mistake not, Sir, you have promis'd it to me already.

Aye, I did promise it to you, that's true, but I have thought better on it since, for my Wife advises me not to be too hasty in parting with it, because, says she, if you keep it till the End of the Election, and it comes to be a casting Vote, you may chance to get Money for it.

I have lost all Patience. — Sdeath, and have I for this contended with the Highest Pow'rs though in an inferior Station? — rail'd at Alder∣men! — libel'd Judges! — abus'd Bishops! — spoke Evil of Privy Councellors, — and dar'd even to advise Lord Lieutenants, and all to sustain the Cause of a set of Slaves, who have not the Cou∣rage to be free? Who cry up my Cause in Ale∣houses, and when it comes to the push, excuse
themselves from serving me, by acknowledging they are Rascals?
SP.L: O Honour! Honour! whither art thou fled?
When Tradesmen sell their Votes to get them Bread,
When vile Corruption spreads so far, and wide,
That Cits, like Courtiers, with its Current glide?
Yet think not Slaves! your Knavery shall con∣troul,
Or awe the Fierceness of my daring Soul;
For without Interest, Feasting, Votes or Pelf,
Know, ye vile Slaves! — that I'll elect myself.
Those Honours, which I claim, (so much my due)
I'll seize, and wear in spite of Hell, and you.
So shall my Exaltation brighter shew,
When to myself alone my Rise I owe.
Thus the bright Sun, exalted in his Sphere,
Shines forth the peerless Monarch of the Air:
In vain wou'd puny Stars, and lesser Gleams,
Oppose the Strength of his o'erpowering Beams,
For soon as he his golden Mantle spreads,
The twinkling Host hide their diminish'd Heads,
Stately he reigns unrival'd, and alone,
And lighting others, takes his Light from none.

TRAILER.HI: The End of the first ACT.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE a Chamber in Firebrand's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Firebrand is discover'd Writing, Papers and Books about him in great Abundance.

SP.P:
SO! — I have made shift to finish this Address at last, and may now take Breath a little. — Well, I profess this is a damn'd Age we live in! — no more Honour stirring, I vow to God, than if they were the Days of Pope Joan, or Cardinal Wolsey of famous and corrupt Memo∣ry؛ a Love of Pelf has so diffus'd itself through all Stations of Life, that you will find none who are free from it. A Whore with Modesty, a Law∣yer with Honesty, or a Devotee without Hypocrisy, you may possibly find; but a Man who hates Mo∣ney is a Prodigy, to be met with no where. — A good Thought that! — let me put it down — But hold, if I mistake not, I have Notes here ex∣pressive of the same Sentiment already, — O yes, here they are — First, Commons Rogues! Alder∣men Rogues! Lords Rogues! Bishops Rogues! Judges Rogues! Privy Council Rogues! Lord
Lieutenants Rogues! and his Majesty (God bless him) not much better than he ought to be. — A fine Catalogue this! — we are well govern'd by such Rulers? — Egad I'll run my Head into a Pil∣lory But some of them shall know of it. — snatches the Pen to write. — But stay! — it may not be so prudent to write any Thing till I have first dispatch'd this Address, which that I may the sooner do, I will give it a second Read∣ing, and send it to the Press immediately.

P.Q:
“That you are all a Parcel of Numb-Skulls, Asses, Tom Noodles and Ninny-Hammers, will, I believe, be pretty apparent to yourselves, when I tell you that your Obstinacy in refu∣sing to elect me, puts me under the Neces∣sity of informing you, that there is no Person in this City so proper to represent you as myself. For G—d Zounds! (to talk calmly) what wou'd you be at? Is it my Inability to stuff your Paunches with the most delicate Food, or my Honesty in refusing to solicit af∣ter the mean customary Manner, that deprives me of your Favour? — If it be the first, with what Face can you expect a Dinner from me, who have always declar'd my Ab∣horrence of that Practice; or why expect I should Flatter, whom you all know to be an
Enemy to Fawning? and yet these are the only Methods, (base as they are) by which you seem resolv'd to be won. — Well Slaves! do! go on your own Way, never leave fol∣lowing Corruption, till you find the Pope at your Doors, the Pretender in your Chambers, the Devil in your Hearts, and Slavery every where; till your Bodies become as groveling as your Minds, and the Aldermen erect an Inqui∣sition to broil Free Citizens. And yet all this does not shame you! — No! — 'tis in vain I ring Freedom in your Ears, when the ver first Tinkle of Glasses, Flaggons, and Quart Pots, drives it out again, and you become as enamour'd of Slavery as ever. By which you shew, you are of the true breed of Circe's Hogs, who had rather lye wallowing in the Filth of your accustom'd Drunkenness, and Gluttony; than, by abstaining a little, enjoy the sober Blessings of Reason, Virtue, and Li∣berty. But why shou'd I take so much Pains, or disturb my own Repose, to save a set of Fellows from Ruin, who seem resolv'd on their own Destruction? Did I consult my own Interest only, I should let them swim with the Stream, but Conscience which over∣rules all other Considerations, will not suffer me to see you quietly make away with yourselves. —No, ye scald Dogs! I love you, and that
is the Reason, that, cost me what pains it will, I am resolved at all Hazards to be your Representative; and this, not out of any vain Motive of raising myself above my Fellows, but through a Consciousness of my own Abi∣lities, which informs me, no Person else can do it so well; as for the other Candidates, who are Rivals with me in your Favour, I swear, by the Majesty of a Free Citizen, they are but mere Botches compar'd with me; Fellows who are as ignorant as designing, and who only make love to their own Fortunes by courting you, and how they will use you, when they get the Key of the Pantry into their own Hands, may be learn'd from the Behaviour of their Predecessors; who, while they wanted your Favour, were as cringing as Spaniels, but when they had no farther Occa∣sion for it, grew as fastidious and insolent as Lap-Dogs. — Therefore Gentlemen, be wary in your Choice for the future, — look sharp about you — choose one who is worthy to re∣present you. — I have told you over and over again, who I am, and if it seems meet to your Reason to elect me, I promise you, no Mastiff was ever truer to his Master's Inte∣rest, than I will be to yours, I will watch Night and Day for your Preservation, and the Wolf shall sooner snap away my share of the
Provender, than touch one Morsel of yours. In short, I will say no more, but if you do not elect me, you will be the greatest Slaves, Blockheads, Knaves, Asses, and Scoundrels, that ever sold City's Liberties. But if you do elect me, not Rome in all her Glory will be able to produce such a set of brave Citizens, Then will you find, in serving me you have serv'd yourselves, Plenty will then be the com∣mon Lot of all, and you may be assur'd, that as my Belly encreases in Bulk, yours will also swell in Proportion; which being the strong∣est Motive I have at present to offer, I con∣clude ”your affectionate Brother,

SP.P: Well this is a pretty pungent Epistle, and will not fail, I believe, to Stimulate. — Here Squirt! come forth here, I'll have it copy'd fair, and send it to the Press immediately.
Was you with Puff the Printer, to bid him come to me?
I was, Sir. He said he would only stay to digest two or three Volumes of black Puddings, he was putting to the Press, and he'd be with you immediately.
What do you mean by that, Sir?

Why Sir, vulgarly speaking, he was at his Dinner — but I thought as the Expression was a
little metaphorical (as you say yourself) it might have pleas'd you.

Well, witty Masters, I see, will have witty Servants, for the Wit that falls from our Mouths, is like the Scraps that fall from our Ta∣ble, they both serve for their Nutriment one way or another. — but here, Sirrah, take this Address, and see that you copy it over fair, for the Prin∣ter against he comes, and let not your Vanity lead you to make any Alterations in it, no, not in the very Spelling; for I'd have you to know, Sirrah, I write too correctly to have any Thing mended.
I will Sir.

And d'ye hear,— bring me the Aqua Vitae Bottle that's in yon Closet, to open my Fancy a little — for I intend to write a second Address immediately. — But Zounds! what Noise is that in the next Chamber?A Noise is heard within.
I'll go see.Exit.

I'll be hang'd but this is some of Fusti∣an's Rants, the Rogue makes a Windmill of my House with his practising, as he calls it. — He brings in as many Machines, as wou'd carry on a Siege, and with his perpetual clattering of them, quite disturbs my Meditations; only I have a more than common Love for the Rogue, I should e'er this have given him warning.
How now! what's the Matter?

Ah Sir, poor Fustian your Lodger is lying within there in the most terrible way, — he has well nigh broke all his Ribs by a fall from the Ceiling, — I don't know how he got there, but certain it is, it has almost kill'd him. — See where he comes, as pale and dismal as the Spirit of his own Banquo.

'Tis even as you say, Squirt! He is as like Banquo as one Spirit can be like another.
"Nay never shake your gorey Locks at me,
"You cannot say 'twas I did it."
For pity's Sake, Firebrand, forbear, I stand more in need of your Medicines, than your Jests. I am so bruis'd by a damn'd fall I got, that I am afraid I shall never recover it.

How! Despair of Recovery, and a Clis∣ter-pipe so near you? — Why, Man, if you were dead, I can bring you to Life again. — Here, Squirt, step, and bring me the strengthening Plai∣ster, that lies below in the Shop, I'll make you as sound as a Roach presently.
I am afraid it is past your Art — O my Ribs! my Ribs! my Ribs!
Prithee leave those damn'd Faces, and tell me how you came by the Fall. You that are so us'd to dying, methinks, ought to bear your Disaster more patiently — but how happen'd it?

Why, you must know, being about to play the Tragedy of Oedipus soon, and not liking that clumsy way the Actors have always practis'd of throwing a sham Person off of the Tower instead of him; I consider'd how I might re∣medy this Indecorum, and observing that the Fellows who fly from the Tops of Steeples, do it by Means of a Groove fasten'd to their Breasts, I got one of them made, and tying a Rope to the Ceiling, attempted to slide down, but un∣luckily for me, e'er I got half way, my Balance forsook me, and I fell on my Side. — 'twas a mer∣cy twas not the Stage it happen'd on, or I shou'd be laught at most inordinately.

Well, Fustian, have good Heart, I hope to see you do it with more Success yet. — You ought to get a Tumbler to give you two, or three Lessons on these Matters, that you may be in less Danger from your Agility.

DIV3.P: But hold, here's the Plaister — leave off shrink∣ing, and let me apply it to your Side peaceably — 'twill pain you a little indeed at first, but you'll soon get over it.

SP.P:
Get over the Devil! What! is not my Pain great enough already, but you must strive to encrease it? Take your Plaister away and be
damn'd to it. — For as I shall Answer the Death I owe, I find myself well at the very Sight of it.

And pray, Sir, if the Sight of it can effect so much good, what must not the Application? That certainly wou'd have made you immortal. — But here, Squirt, take it away, seeing there's no farther use for it.

I think, Firebrand, all your Medicines have the same admirable Property with your Plai∣ster, they do better at the outside of the Belly than within it, and to effect the Cure of the Patient, you need only shew them.
I thank God, they are none of your mar∣cid, dead, unoperating Drugs, they, like my Writings, have a Spirit in them extraordinary. — But what Paper is that you took out of your Pocket?

'Tis the Correction of a favourite Play of mine, call'd the Revenge, which I intend to ex∣hibit soon, and which I wou'd be glad to have your Opinion of beforehand. Now you must know this Play begins as all good Tragedies ought, with a Storm; and indeed, to say the Truth, it is no other than a Storm all through. Now I perceiving that nothing pleases People so well as Tempests in Plays, I have added a few Lines of my own, in order to make it still more Tempestuous. — Hark, and you shall hear
if I have not done the Author Justice. — His Play begins thus.

Q.L: "Whether first Nature, or long want of Peace,
"Has wrought my Mind to this, I cannot tell;
"But Horrors now are not displeasing to me.
"I like this rocking of the Battlements.
"Rage on, ye Winds! burst Clouds! and Waters roar!

SP.P: So far are the Author's own Lines. — now for mine.

Q.L: Let Neptune swell, till his proud, haughty Waves,
Scaling the Mansions of immortal Jove,
Shall deluge Heaven, and drown the very Gods.

SP.P: By H—n's! that's a fine Thought!
Aye, but I believe you will say this is still finer.

Q.L: Let the four Winds at once together blow,
Till meeting in Earth's Centre, there, they fight,
And with their Conflict sink it down to Hell.

SP.P: O Jesu! but that is a very far fetch'd Thought.

Is it not? — Igad, I defy your Shakespears, your Otways, or your Lees to produce any Thing
in their Works like it. They are Tame com∣par'd to me, as you shall see by the following, for I carry the Thought still farther.

Q.L: Let Hell itself affrighted with the Din
Leap up, and seizing Earth's deserted Space,
Confound all Nature with the horrid Change.
So shall the Heavens with Monsters strange be fill'd,
And Gods, like Dolphins, tumble in the Deep:
Men shall sink down to where Hell stood before,
And Devils roam about where Men did dwell;
So to their Contraries shall all Things turn,
Fire, freeze like Ice, and Ice like Fire burn;
Darkness shall overspread the Face of Day,
And Night, like Sol, emit a lucid Ray:
Till Chance to Chaos shall his Reign restore,
And Honour, Love, and Friendship be no more.

SP.P: How do you like that Thought now? is it not noble?

By my Father's Great Shade! 'tis such a Confusion of the Elements as I never heard before; it is (as Milton says) Confusion worse confounded, and excels even the bellowing of Baralipton Bomboma∣chides, who, they say, was the natural Son of Aeolus, God of the Winds, and did every Thing by his Inspiration. But now, Fustian! Your Hand's in, I'll tell you how you can oblige me with your Fan∣cy.
turn them Devils who roam the Earth into Aldermen, for, methinks I shou'd be glad to see them damn'd, tho' it were only in Description.
O Sir, it wou'd be destroying the Dig∣nity of Tragedy, to put particular Satire in it; but have Patience till the next Comedy I alter, and you'll see how I'll handle them.
Well, pray let it be soon. — But what's the Reason, Fustian, you never write a whole Play?

Pshaw! I leave that for Fellows who have less Capacity and Judgment than myself. I shew my Parts in correcting what the best Authors have wrote, in which I think I do wisely, for did I write any thing myself, perhaps the World wou'd not think it so good, so that I mump the Criticks there, for, by only mending others, I get all the Reputation of an Author, without giving them any thing to rail at.
Well, you're a crafty Fellow, and that your very Enemies allow you. But have you any Thing more that you wou'd ask my Opinion of? For to tell you the Truth, I am in some Haste to go write myself.

I will detain you but to hear one Altera∣tion I have made at the End of the Play, where Zanga is carry'd off to be executed; which, under Favour of so great an Author, was a very mean
Thing of him, to have the grand Hero of a Play carry'd to Execution, like one of our Tyburn Male∣factors, is most pitiful. I see nothing in George Barnwell half so shocking. For besides the Inde∣corum of making a Hero dye that Way, it de∣prives the Actor of the Reputation he might have got in performing it well. — Now Sir, how do you think I Remedy this? Why, as they offer to lay Hands on me, not thinking, I have any Wea∣pon, whip, pulls I it out,—and ere you cou'd well reckon one, plunges it into my own Entrails. — See Sir, I will both say the Words, and do the Action, that you may Judge of both together. — Now I am stabb'd — now I fall, — and here's the last Speech I utter.

Q.L: Ah! ye vile Dogs! and did you basely think
To bind my Limbs, like Felons, on a Wheel?
Or to a Gibbet give my royal Carcase?
I, who from Moorish Kings derive my Blood,
And am more Great than he, at whose Com∣mand
You'd do the Deed. — But know, ye grov'ling Slaves!
I have a Soul too great, to bear such Insults,
And will, though kill'd, have this remaining Joy,
That I can still defy you. — hence! — away!
And leave me to enjoy my Fate alone.—
O Vengeance, I have follow'd thee too far!
For thee I sold a Friend, whose only Fault
Was but a single Blow. — O lost Alonzo!
Worthy a better Fate! — O Leonora! —
More wou'd I say, but Heavy-handed Death,
Comes with his murd'ring Palms to stop my Breath.
And now I feel a Rumbling in my Guts,
Which all my Entrails to Confusion puts,
Lungs, Livers, Lights, are jumbl'd all together!
And now I'm carry'd off — the Lord knows whi∣ther.
Roar Tempests! roar! swell Seas! and Billows rowl!
To Earth I give my Corps, — to Hell — my Soul.Flops.

SP.P: O Heavens! what a Flop there was, as if he intended to dig that Grave in the Floor, he is now going to. Well! I always thought till now that living well was a Man's best Course, but I find there are some, who can dye much better than they live.—How are you now, Fustian?
As well as any Man in my Condition can possibly be,—don't I seem as if I was dead?
Fore-George, you look as absolutely dead, as if I myself had given you the Potion.
I don't stir then?
Not a Jot, not a Jot.

Nay dont flatter me,—Friends ought to be
candid with one another,—do you think, as I now lye, People would not take me for a Corps?
Aye and bury you,—for let me perish, but you look as dead, as any live Man I ever saw. —Betterton himself could not do it better.

Starting up,Betterton be damn'd!— he die with me?—were he alive again I'd die with him for his Ears.—Look'ye Mr. Firebrand! I tell it you, and you may believe it upon my Word, the old Actors were all Sots, compared to us now living; they thought if they stuck to their Parts, and represented Things, as the Poets Sentiments naturally suggested them, their Business was done; they never considered, how a pityful Thought might be helped out by an Heroic Ges∣ture; they were all for your correct pieces, and such as when once understood, left them nothing to do; now I, for my Part, love to shew my Skill where the Poetry's at the Worst, and am most successful in my Action, where the Words have least Meaning.

Egad! and so you are, I can witness for that, nay, and when you put in Things of your own, the Applause is not a Whit the less loud for it; and in this, you seem to vie with Merry An∣drew, who is at once the Author, and Actor of
hs own Speeches. This in a less skilfull Person might seem absurd; but to one of your great Ca∣pacity, all Things are allowable.
And to one of your vast Judgment, all Incongruities are pardonable.
Ah! Fustian, 'tis you that has the Genius.
And you the Taste.
You tickle the Ladies, with your sweet Fancy.
And you the Commons, with your noble Eloquence.
You are the Shakespear of the Age.
And you the Demosthenes.
When you act, the whole House is in one Uproar.
And when you harangue, the whole City is ready to run mad with Transport.
You have no Enemies, but such as are Blockheads.
And the greatest Men of the Age, glory in being your Friends.
But of all Friends, I love you best, Fustian.
And I you, Firebrand.
Then as a Token of our Amity, let us kiss, for surely never were two Hearts so closely united.
Agreed — here they kiss — again, and again, dear Firebrand!

Enough, enough, Fustian.—'Fore-God any Fools, looking at us now, would take us to be but little wiser than themselves; but you remember the saying of our Friend Horace, Dulce est desi∣pere in loco, and the greatest Men have their weak Sides.—But I wonder, this rascally Printer does not come, I sent for him an Hour ago to print me an Address, — A Plague rot him that he is not here.—O here the Rogue comes, and looks as big, as if he had been appointed Sheriff, for the Year ensuing.—Now shall you see, how I'll revenge myself for his Stay by being witty on him.
O! Ho! Master Puff, have you made Shift to come at last? pray Sir whether are you, or I the Author, that I should wait on you thus?
You are Sir,—I acknowledge your Su∣periority.

Do you so!—marry 'tis well, I can get so large a Concession from you, for the Booksellers of late Days, behave as if they thought the Authors no better than their Journeymen. And pray Sir, seeing you know your Duty, how happened it, you came not sooner?

Faith Sir, I did but stay to put on my la∣ced Waistcoat, have my best Wig dressed, and my
Gold headed Cane brought me from the Toyman's; for as I knew I was to wait on your Honour, I did not care to disgrace your House by looking too like a Tradesman.

Hell and the Devil!—did you ever hear the like, Fustian? Here's a mechanical Rogue for you, thinks his Trade a Disgrace to him.—Sirrah! the Vanity with which you would apologize for your Neglect, is more impudent than the Neglect itself; and give me Leave to tell you, that had you been as slow in puffing ill Author's Works, as you are in coming to print mine, you would have wanted such an Excuse to make.—That I believe Fustian was home upon him.aside to the other.
O Curst home! Curst home!
Ah dear Sir I know you do but jest with me, for indeed you great Wits have such a Way of being smart upon us simple Tradesmen. —But pray Sir what's your Business?

Business! Puff, Business!—Now for some∣thing witty upon that! —O I have it.—Why in∣deed Puff, my Business with you may be properly called no Business; —for had I any Business, d'ye see, I could have no Leisure to write, and having no Leisure to write, consequently my Business with you, would have been no Business.—Ha, Ha, Ha, Ha! did you note that Fustian? there I believe I was smart on him again.

Oh damn'd smart! damn'd smart! — Pox on it, this Fellow will run away with all the Credit of the Wit, tho' it be my particular Pro∣fession,—Egad I'll try if I cannot be smart upon him too aside— coming up to the Bookseller. Puff! Prithee how do them seven Volumes of your last Novel go off, which you gave us upon your Ho∣nour to be so good a one?—Do the People bring their Silver as fast as you bid them?—Ha!
Why really, Sir, they go off a little better than your Shakespear revised would do, dare you venture print it: And yet I hear the Criticks say, 'tis none of your worst Performance neither.

asideOh Jupiter Ammon! but my Bolt's shot,—the Rogue has more Wit than I thought he had;—well, I profess, I was very unfortunate to mention Books; but indeed, I spoke it without thinking, as a Wit ought to do.

Lookye Master Fustian; I know you woud-be Wits, look upon us Tradesmen to be meer Fools, and never condescend to speak to us but with a Sneer. But if it does not grate your noble Nature, to benefit by the Advice of so mean a person, I would warn you how you made too free with Laughing, for be assured however your Rants may pass with the Vulgar for sublime Dicti∣on, they never will be so stupid as to mistake your insipid Jesting for Comedy. — Besides, I I have another Thing to tell you, which though
no Joke, may serve to hit you as well, and that is, if you are not more moderate in your Puffs for the future, it will not be consistent either with my Modesty or Safety to print them.—I met just now Punchinello from the other House, who ra∣ted me on Account of your last Copy of Verses; he called me, numskull, Puppy, medling Fool, Wooden-headed Rogue, (and so forth) and won∣dered why to gratify a Vagabond, I would asperse so near a Relation.

How! had Punch the Impudence to call me a Vagabond? By the L—d I'll have him before my Lord Chief Justice for the Insult; for I'd have the Rascal to know, that notwithstanding I condes∣cend to play, more for my own Amusement, than, to divert the Publick, that I am still a Gen∣tleman.

Aye, he must be as great a Blockhead, as Punch himself, who can doubt that after all I have written to prove it.—But now I talk of wri∣ting, Puff, I have the prettyest pen'd Address,—such a Whapper,—I-gad if you don't get your Wife a Capuchin out of the Profits of it, I'll be content to go naked all my Lifetime.—Shall I read it to you?
By all Means Sir, for if I print it, it is necessary I should hear it beforehand, that I may form some Judgment of the Merits of it, for I print nothing but what's good I assure you.
How Sir! you judge of my Works!— I submit my Works to your Judgment!—I'll see you hanged first,—and for a Farthing now I would not let you print it at all.
Sir I beg your Pardon; but I thought, you did in some Measure ask my Judgment, when you desired me to hear it.
No Sir, I desired you to hear it, that you might praise it, not Judge of it.—Did you ever hear such Insolence, Fustian.

I tell you Mr. Firebrand, 'tis the Way of all these sorry Booksellers, set one of them in a Shop, with Books about him, and if he be ever so great a Blockhead, he'll think from the very Na∣ture of his Profession, he's obliged to have Un∣derstanding.
Aye, and judge of Author's Works with as much Positiveness, as if they were the Authors themselves. Is that your Modesty, Sir?

Nay Gentlemen, I beg your Pardon, if I have been too forward, in speaking my Opinion before such learned Judges, but indeed, the Truth is, my Customers talked so long to me, upon these Matters, that I began to fancy I had Taste, but if you think otherwise, I am contented to pass only for what you would have me.
This qualifies, and now you shall see the Address. — Here Squirt! bring forth the Manus∣cript.
But what's the Matter? Why do you stare so?

O Lord Sir! Here has been Mr. Busy Body the Barber, who came out of Breath, to tell you, that the Aldermen, and Commons are privately as∣sembled at the Hall, and intend to steal an Election without you.

Oons! bring me my Sword, Blunderbuss and Pistols, and see that these last be double charg'd. — I'll repair to the Hall immediately, and put every Man of them to the Sword, or they shall do as I'd have them.
Mr. Puff, let us not desert out Friend in this Extremity, but run after, and help him with our Interest.
With all my Heart — lead on.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE a Hall.
DIV3.STAGE: Whittington, and the Aldermen sitting, the Com∣mons walking to and fro, in great Confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.P: FOR Heaven's Sake, Cryer! order Si∣lence, or we shall never be able to come to an Election.
Silence! there.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Com.
SP.P: We'll Silence for none, nor will we have any Election till our Wrongs are redress'd.
Peace! I say.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: No, no Peace, till our Wrongs are re∣dress'd, we will have Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Com.
SP.P: Well urg'd, Brother! stick to that Point, — We will have Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Com.
SP.P: Aye, we will be the Dupes of Alder∣men no longer. We will have Justice.
Justice! Justice! Justice! Justice! Justice!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Ald.
SP.P: Was ever such Phrenzy heard? — In what my Friends, wou'd you have Justice?

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: We cant tell. — Firebrand will be here just now, and let us know, in what we are wrong'd.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Com.
SP.P: Aye, he will make it appear to us, that we are grosly abus'd, though we ourselves know nothing of the Matter.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.P: Gentlemen, the Phrenzy of that Wretch Firebrand, has infected these poor Creatures, they know not what they wou'd have.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Ald.
SP.P: Then, seeing they are non Compos, let us proceed to an Election without them. —There's a Rule in our Tuesday Book, which says, no Man shall be suffer'd to vote, unless he be in his right Senses.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P: And with Reason is that Law made, for if every Madman might have a Liberty of vot∣ing for his Brother, we shou'd have a fine crazy House of it.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Ald.
SP.P: Most justly observ'd, Brother. — there∣fore, are you all agreed we come to an Election without them.
Aye, Aye, — their voting will but con∣found us — proceed, proceed to name the Mem∣ber:

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Com.
SP.P: Ha! hear you that Brethren! they are going to deprive us of our Priviledge of voting. — This is of a Piece with their other Tyranny.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: Aye, they stop at no Villainy to op∣press us. — What shall we do to prevent them?

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Com.
SP.P: Best confound them with Bawling, till Firebrand comes, and then he'll manage them.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Com.
SP.P: That's good Advice, — therefore let us set up all our Throats together.

DIV3.STAGE: Here, they all fall a Bawling, and Huzza∣ing, in the midst of which, Firebrand enters.

SP.P: Ha! what Roaring's this? — I'll be damn'd, but the Member's already chosen, and I am come too late. — If it prove so, I will, in the first fit of my Rage, murther Mayor, Aldermen, Commons, and all of them. Rushing in among them Zounds! and Blood, ye Dogs! what's this ye have done?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Com.
SP.P: O, here's Firebrand.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: Our deliverer! — hail! hail! — you are come in happy Time.

Aye, to be a Witness to your Perfidy, ye corrupt Slaves! — But say! have ye not sold yourselves? have you not entail'd Slavery on your Posterity for ever, by voting contrary to your Consciences? — Say! is not the Member already chosen?

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: Not at all, good Master Firebrand. — We wou'd not do your Merit that Injustice, — we stay'd for you.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Com.
SP.P: Aye, we are all to a Man for you.

SP.SPEAKER: 5th Com.
SP.P: For your Sake, we have quarrel'd with our best Customers.

SP.SPEAKER: 6th Com.
SP.P: And rather lose our Business, than our Liberty.
There spoke the Voice of Honour! — You begin to have the true Roman Mettle in you, so stick by me, and you shall see, how I'll manage these Grey Beards.

SP.SPEAKER: 7th Com.
SP.P: Souse them, brave Firebrand! Souse them! — leave them not Teeth enough to chew their Custard.

SP.SPEAKER: 8th Com.
SP.P: Aye, they wou'd have depriv'd us, just now, of our Right of voting.
How! — had they the Impudence?

SP.SPEAKER: 8th Com.
SP.P: Yes indeed, yes indeed.
So well they shall pay for it. Goes over to the Aldermen. — Ha! damn'd Divan! select Committee of Rascals! Council of Lucifer! — What new Oppression are you hatching now? — ha!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.P: What! this Madman come! — then there will be no doing of Business. — Let us break up Council, and go every Man to his own home.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Ald.
SP.P: Aye, aye, — we declare the Court dis∣solv'd. — Brethren push forward.

DIV3.STAGE: As they are going Firebrand draws out his Pistols and stops them.

SP.P:
Stand! — or by the glorious Fame con∣sequent to great Actions, this Blunderbuss goes off among you. — What you Slaves! do you think to sport thus with our Patience? to go▪ and leave our
Evils unredress'd, but it is your Guilt that wou'd urry you away from the hearing of your Villai∣nies.—But you shall stay Slaves, till I have run over the whole Catalogue of them. — I will thrust your Crimes back into your own Bellies, and if you be too harden'd to Blush, Fear shall extract from you that Remorse, which Conscience refuses, — Nay, no stirring, or —

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Ald.
SP.P: What you Villain! wou'd you commit a Rape upon our inviolable Persons? Force us to elect you, whether we will, or no? —Down with him, Brethren, if he offers to obstruct our Passage, — down with him.

And, I say, Brethren, if they offer to de∣part, without doing us Justice, put them all to the Sword. — You have a Precedent for it in History, for when the Gauls sack'd Rome, they cut the Throats of all the Senators, who were their Al∣dermen.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Com.
SP.P: Never fear us for discharging our Du∣ty, there are none of us here, that have not learn'd our Exercise, and if they put us to it, can kill them Methodically.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: Aye, aye, we may venture to do as he bids us — he understands the Law. — So have at you Grey Beards.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.P: Hold, hold, Gentlemen! wou'd you murther your Magistrates to please a Madman?

SP.SPEAKER: 2nd Com.
SP.P: Well, do us Justice then, we do not love Blood; but be assured Blood or Justice we will have.
Aye Aye, Blood, or Justice! Blood, or Justice!

SP.SPEAKER: 2nd Ald.
SP.P: Were ever such Blood-thirsty Rogues seen? if we don't do something shortly to appease them, they will certainly kill us.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P: Aye, they have lost all Humanity with their Reason. But what's to be done?

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Ald.
SP.P: Best desire their Leader, to draw them off a little, till we resolve on something.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P: I will try, whether he has so much Mer∣cy. — Courteous, right noble, and magnanimous Firebrand, let us, though Enemies, obtain some Truce from your Fury, while we think of some Means for a Reconciliation.

All Reconcilement with Aldermen is to me odious; yet to let you see I am not so implaca∣ble, but I can sometimes descend to Moderation, — go, and think of some Means to pacify me, and my enraged Commons. See that the Condi∣tions be such, as I particularly approve of, — I — mark that, I — and five Minutes is all the Time, I give you to deliberate.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P: This is a tyrannical Rogue. — Well Brethren, I have got Time for a Conference, what do you resolve on?

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Ald.
SP.P: That he should be hang'd, had I my Will.

SP.SPEAKER: 2nd Ald.
SP.P: And so say I.
And so say all of us.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Ald.
SP.P: Aye, I believe there would be a ne∣mine contradicente in that Case, but as the Matter now stands, we must do something shortly to appease them, or I am afraid they will hang us, five Minutes is all the Time he has given us to debate.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.P: Now as I hope to be a Plumb, I never was in a worse Vein for thinking, in all my Life.

SP.SPEAKER: 2nd Ald.
SP.P: Nor I.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P: Nor I.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Ald.
SP.P: Nor I.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.P: I never was right Master of my Reason, since my last Surfeit of Canary.

SP.SPEAKER: 2nd Ald.
SP.P: A too frequent Use of Pudding has destroyed in me, all that was mental.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P: And for my Part, I never attempt to think, that I do not fall asleep immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th ld.
SP.P: Nor ca, but when Money's in the Case; I am a sharp Rogue at a Bargain, but have no Head for Politicks.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P: Then seeing, Gentlemen, we cannot think of any better Sratagm, what say you to a Bribe?
Aye, a Bribe, I like that way of a Bribe.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.P: A Bribe!

SP.SPEAKER: 2nd,
SP.P: A Bribe!

SP.SPEAKER: 3d,
SP.P: A Bribe!

SP.SPEAKER: 4th,
SP.P: A Bribe!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st,
SP.P: Blessed be the Head that first invented Bri∣bing; 'tis the shortest Way of coming to an Agreement.

SP.SPEAKER: 2nd,
SP.P: Aye, it saves a Man the Trouble of plot∣ting, he who has Money need never Reason.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d,
SP.P: No, for that convinces much faster. I re∣member an old Prophecy, I learned when a Boy, which says England should one Day or other fall by a Bribe; as it is in Verse, and pithy, I will for your Instruction repeat it.

Q.L: When Things shall come to such a Pass, I wis,
That Money more than Virtue valued is.
When Knaves to Patriotism shall pretend,
And sell the Cause they did at first defend;
Then tremble Englonde, for withouten Lie,
You may conclude your Ruin then is nighe.
What neither civil Broil nor foreign Fone,
Cou'd e'ere subdue, Corruption has o'retbrown.
Then gird thy Loins, O Wight of Worth, and flee,
Englonde I ween, will be no Place for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Ald.
SP.P:
A most veritable Prophecy truly, and he who lives three Thousand Years hence, will cer∣tainly
see it fulfilled. — But to the Bribe in Hand, Gentlemen, how shall it be ordered?

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Ald.
SP.P: Hang him Slave, — 'tis such an abusive Wretch, that my Conscience grumbles he should profit by his Knavery.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P: Ha! say you so?—then I have a Thought come into my Head, how we may divide him, and his Commons, much cheaper,—but for fear he should hear it, I'll whisper it to you.they whisper.

A ha! — now they whisper! — now they plot!—You see, my Friends, to what Streights our Unanimity drives them; — do but stand true to my Interest, and the Sun shall sooner desert his Sphere, than I forsake you.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Com.
SP.P: We believe you, Noble Firebrand, we believe you, — and will stand by you, to the last Drop of our Blood.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: Aye, we will acknowledge no Supe∣riour, but Firebrand. Huzza! for Firebrand.
Huzza! Huzza! Huzza!
By my Rod, and Chain, a fine Stra∣tagem; — but hark! they begin to mutiny, and 'tis Time, you put it in Execution.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P: That I will immediately. — Goes over to the other Hem! Firebrand, this way a little, — this way.

following himWell, are you come to a Resolution at last? — 'tis well you have, your five Minutes were almost expired, and our Pati∣ence
along with them, but say, tell me instantly, what have you resolved on, — have you! — have you! — have you! —

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P: Peace! good Firebrand, Peace! and let us have no more Bickering, — the Time is come at length, I hope, that that Hell-born Fiend, called by you Writers, Discord, and who has, of late, presided too much in our Assemblies, shall hide her hated Face, and in her Stead, Rosey-cheeked Peace, that ever blooming, and immortal Goddess, riding on the Wings of Plenty, shall shed Friendship upon all Hearts, like an ambrosial Dew, — while the Graces, smit with our Union —
Less Rhetorick and more Matter, good Mr. Alderman! — to the Point! to the Point.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P: Why then Sir, the Short is, that the Aldermen, having weighed Matters, are come to a Resolution, of doing Justice to your extraordinary Merits, by giving you a Place.
Ha! a Place!

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P:
Yes Sir, Collector of a certain Tax, called Drivel-Money. 'Tis a Cess, has been much litigated, of late Years, by a Set of sturdy Papists, who think, they have a Right to cough, belch, spit out, or blow their Noses, equal with other Poppets of a loyal, and Protestant Denomination. Now Sir, considering the Terror, you usually go cloathed with, and the extreme Vehemence, with which
you urge all Processes, we thought we could not do better, than by lodging such an Authority in your Hands, put you in a Condition of retrie∣ving it.

Ha! Villain, is this your Plot? is this the Trap, you have laid to ensare my spotless Honour? — Damnation! What can you see in this Face, so reprobate? do these Lineaments discover a corrupt Heart. — Hell and Furies! I shall run mad at the Insult, — in a low Voice. But don't be frighted Sir, it is not you I blame, but those who employ∣ed you, loud, Had I committed Sacriledge, killed my Father, whor'd my Mother, or defiled the Bed of my best Friend, it were then enough to suspect me of so base a Crime, — low. How much may it be worth? loud Hell! devil! Fire! Flames! and Fury! low, don't answer me unless you think the Place worth my Accepting, loud. No, no! I am cool, I don't resent this Insult as I ought, or my Nails had e'er this been buried an Ell deep in the Flesh of you. Traytor to mine Honour, why do I bear it? low. See that you're in Earnest, Friend, loud, for should you offer to deceive me as you have my Brethren hitherto, I'de tear you to Pieces, you Dog you!

aside.So! this Fellow has at last made shift to let me see the Place will not be disagreeable to him— Sir I beg Pardon for heating you thus, but I did not
think, to have incur'd your Displeasure, by offering you fifteen hundred a Year.
Sir, the Place is a good Place, a profitable Place, and was it not given by Aldermen, wou'd be an honourable Place, but —
Why, Sir, if you suspect the Aldermen's Word, the Lord Mayor shall make it good to you.

The Lord Mayor is a worthy Gentleman, an honourable Gentleman. — I have no Quarrel to him, — and were I dispos'd to accept the Place, think I might trust him. — But, Oh! how shall I excuse this Conduct to my faithful Commons?— how Answer their just Reproaches? will they not cry as I go along the Street, there goes Firebrand the Trimmer. — How will my great Heart quail at the hearing of these Taunts? Then shall I wish, all my new acquir'd Honours bury'd fifty Fathom deep in the Sea, and myself along with them. — Would to Heaven, I had never been born, or this Place had never been offer'd me. — O, my Repu∣tation! my Reputation!
Best tell them you were mad, which will easily gain Credit, because the soberer Part of them are inclin'd to think you so already.

Ha! an excellent Thought that. — Faith and so I may,—'twill be a good come off; and help to preserve, some small Shew of Honesty, which is all I desire. These Commons are but a wavering set of
Rogues, uncertain of their own Principles, who, as they cry'd up my Cause without Reason, may hereafter run it down the same Way: Which for fear they shou'd, I'll be aforehand with them. aside — Where, Sir, is this Commission you talk of? I don't know, if you had it ready to slip into my Hands now, but the Thing would tempt me.
Sir, do but speak to the Commons to re∣concile them, while the Clerk is making it out, and you shall have it immediately.
Well, I believe, I may venture to trust them for once, if they deceive me, 'twill be but setting the Commons on their backs again. Goes over to the Commons. Gentlemen! I crave your Audience.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Com.
SP.P: Silence! there, Firebrand's going to speak.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: Silence! there, Silence!

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Com.
SP.P: Now for a Roast upon the Alder∣men.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Com.
SP.P: Aye, he has been whetting his Spleen against them all this while, and we shall have the Substance of it, come out plump in this Oration.

SP.SPEAKER: 5th Com.
SP.P: See, how prettily he waves his Hand∣kerchief, and adjusts himself for the ensuing Dis∣course. The Seeds of Oratory are sown very thick in that same Firebrand.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Com.
SP.P: Aye, and Honesty.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Com.
SP.P: He's rigidly Honest that's certain.

SP.SPEAKER: 5th Com.
SP.P: A contemner of Bribes!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: And all false Honours!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Com.
SP.P: Conscientious to a Fault!

SP.SPEAKER: 6th Com.
SP.P: Virtuous even in his Poverty!

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Com.
SP.P: A very Cato!

Dear Gentlemen! Turn not my Head with these excessive Praises of yours, which Hea∣ven knows, has been but too much distracted al∣ready — Heaven's! what a Time had I on it — O Reason! thou glorious Emanation of the Divi∣nity! how do I rejoice at the finding you? — ah me! What a void hitherto has been this poor Brain of mine? — how has it been haunted with empty Spectres of Liberty, Oppression, and Slavery, which cheating my slav'd Imagination with their fancy'd Forms, have set it a Gadding, like a Will of the Wisp. — I am quite Hagridden by being left to my own Discretion. —O my Friends! what a Blessing 'tis to enjoy one's perfect Senses?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Com.
SP.P: What the Devil's all this for! — do you understand him, Brother?

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: Not I fac! — I hope he is not going to desert our Interest.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Com.
SP.P: O, never fear him for that — 'tis only a Figure of Speech he uses, to make the remain∣ing Part of his Speech fall more heavy on the Al∣dermen.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Com.
SP.P: Like enough! Like enough, — but hear him, Brethren, he speaks again.

You seem all to wonder, Gentlemen, (and with Reason,) at this sudden Alteration in my Deportment. But because your Love to me, claims no less, than a clear Explanation of this Mat∣ter, I will now let you into the secret of it. You must know, that for many Years past, I have been troubl'd with a certain Vertigo in my Head, ap∣proaching nearly, to what People call Madness; occasion'd by an ill Accident, which happen'd to me in one of my Chymical Projections. For as I was searching after the Philosophers Stone, (a Thing, I have since found to be attain'd, only by Faction) it happen'd that by too great an Infusi∣on of the sulphureous Matter, the Projection blew up: and the same Blast, that depriv'd me of half my Sight, did at the same Time carry off half my Reason; so that I grew not utterly Delirious, but as a Man wou'd say, half-witted; a thing plainly to be seen in my Writings, which however sensible in the Main, had a strange Tendency to abuse these worthy Gentlemen, the Aldermen, whom upon the Recovery of my Senses, I find, to be the best Friends of the City: therefore, blame not me, Brethren, but my unfortunate Phrenzy, for having so long misled you. The only Reparation I can now make, is, to advise you to go home, and mind your Occupations, as I intend to do mine. A future Industry may retrieve what your past Idle∣ness
has lost you, in all Emergencies of the City I will never fail to be your Friend. Dixi.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Com.
SP.P: O Heavens! what a Speech here is!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: How is he alter'd?

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Com.
SP.P: O, the uncertainty of human Resolu∣tions!

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Com.
SP.P: Who wou'd have believ'd this, if they had not heard it.

SP.SPEAKER: 5th Com.
SP.P: Well! I will never trust Patriot a∣gain.

SP.SPEAKER: 6th Com.
SP.P: He has certainly taken a Bribe.

SP.SPEAKER: 7th Com.
SP.P: Nay, 'tis but too plain.

SP.SPEAKER: 8th Com.
SP.P: Villain, that he is! — I cou'd tear him to Pieces for selling our Cause thus.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Com.
SP.P: Best leave him to his Conscience; that will be his greatest Tormentor.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: The Rogue! he has no Conscience, nor ever had.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Com.
SP.P: Then you ought to be less surpriz'd at what he has done. — But see! he now Addresses the Aldermen. Let us watch him if he takes a Bribe.
to the Ald.Well, Gentlemen! now you see I have lay'd this Storm of the Commons; I expect your Promise.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.P: Here 'tis, giving a Paper and may the Place do you as much Good, as the Good you labour'd to effect, was devoid of Self-Interest.
Opening the Paper.Why, how's this? Gentlemen! here's nothing but a Blank!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.P: Blank Patriotism, deserves a blank Re∣ward. — How like you the Contrivance, Fire∣brand?
Why, ye Slaves! sure you wou'd not have the Impudence to serve me thus.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.P: Yes faith, yes Faith! your Squib may Hiss now as much as it pleases, 'twill have no Crack at the End of it.

Ha! and is that your dirty Plot, Rascals, to divide me and my Brethren? and do you think with your shallow Stratagems to overreach me. — But know, ye dull Slaves, though I have at your Request, silenc'd the Commons for a Moment, the same Spirit of Oratory, that rouz'd them to you Perdition formerly, shall now Fire them with a fiercer Resentment again you than ever. — Their first Rage did but fret you; but Famine, Fire, Slaughter, and Desolation shall be the Effects of their second Fury.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Ald.
SP.P:
Then, for fear you shou'd, we'll en∣deavour to be aforehand with you. — Here the Aldermen seize him and stop his Mouth, while one of them Addresses the Commons. — Here, Gentle∣men, is your Patriot! your Cato! The Protector of your Liberties! the Contemner of Bribes, and
all underhand Dealing! —This worthy Patriot, (to call him by no worse Name) has at length ma∣nifested his wonderful Integrity, by offering to sell your Interests. — Let it not amaze you, Gentle∣men! he did indeed endeavour to sell them, — and for what think you? why, for less than Esau sold his Birthright, a mess of Pottage. — He sold you for a Blank. — 'Tis true, he thought to have it fill'd with something more substantial, but our Abhorrence of Knavery, wou'd not suffer us to let him benefit by such Treachery. — Your Wolf in the Sheep Skin is now uncas'd, and to your Mercy we leave him.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Com.
SP.P: We believe you, worthy Alderman! we believe you, his Knavery is but too plain.
Yes, worthy Alderman, we believe you, and are henceforward your Friends.
breaking loose.What, ye Rascals! will ye believe these Fellows against me? — I tell you, these Aldermen are the saddest Dogs —

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Com.
SP.P: Stop that filthy Mouth of yours, base Rascal, and learn to speak with more Respect of your Betters.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Com.
SP.P: Aye, I always thought he was a Rogue, but cou'd get nobody to believe me.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Com.
SP.P: Nay, in that you were no wiser than we, we all thought him a Rogue, for that Matter, but never had certain Proof of it till now.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Com.
SP.P: Yes, Brethren, but it must be own'd, of a Knave he has a most bewitching Tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: 5th Com.
SP.P: That's certain. Therefore, for fear it shou'd seduce us farther, let us stop our Ears as often as he attempts to speak to us.Here they stop their Ears.
Hear me!
Pish!
Hear me, I say.
We will not.
What ye Slaves! will ye dare to be thus Obstinate? — hear me, or —
Holla! Holla! Holla! Holla! Holla!
Nay then, come forth my last Recourse, my Ultima ratio Regum. Draws out his Fire-Arms. Silence, ye Dogs! and hear me Speech, or by the Fury you have rais'd in me, these go off among you.

Impudent Rascal! does he threaten us! — Disarm him and kick him out of the Hall. — Down with the Incendiary! — Down with him. Here they Disarm him, and thrust him out of the Hall, crying down with a Firebrand! down with him! down with him,

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Ald.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! — this was an excellent Scheme, to get rid of this Trouble-all, — and we may now without Interruption proceed to an Elec∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Ald.
SP.P: Aye, Brother. But the Day is too far advanc'd, let us defer it till To-morrow, when we shall all meet again.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Ald.
SP.P: Agreed; but before we separate, let us adjourn to some Tavern, and make ourselves merry with Laughing at this Event. The City has ac∣quir'd as much Honour this Day, by the Defeat of this Incendiary, as in that of Wat Tyler, slain by your Lordship's Predecessor, of renown'd, and valiant Memory.

Right: for which Reason, I will have some Device of this notable Stratagem painted, and added to the Dagger in our City Arms. — But come, let us to the Tavern, as you Advise. I long, after so much Business, to re∣cruit my exhausted Spirits. And, as the Father of my People, I will close all our Debates with this short Prayer.

Q.L: May Peace continue still our Isle to bless,
And Faction ever meet the like Success.

TRAILER.HI: The End of the Third and last ACT.

DIV1.HEAD: THE EPILOGUE To be spoken by PUNCH.

LG.L: WELL Gallants! I've broke loose at length, to tell
What strange Disasters have poor Punch befel,
What Plots, of late my Enemies have try'd,
What Int'rest us'd, to have me laid aside:
First, by dull Puffs in Faulkner's venal News,
They both my Person, and my Wife, abuse;
Affirming, that our Jokes for nought are good,
Because forsooth! our Heads are made of Wood;
As if the same of them might not be understood.
Nay, what's still worse, my Province they invade,
And think without me to set up the Trade;
Witness the partial Author of this Day,
Who has not wrote one Word for me to say,
And yet would call his Piece a Puppet Play.
Can ye bear then, ye Royst'rers of the Town,
To see your once lov'd Actor hunted down?
When a vile Player, through his own Default,
Had half this City's Rage upon him brought:
Beaus, Belles, and Scholars, did at once unite,
To do this Fellow's fancy'd Merit Right.
But when true Wit, as just as e'er was stamp'd,
Is by a set of sordid Schemers cramp'd;
Not one of you will set your Throats a Bawling,
Or brandish Stick to keep his Cause from falling.
So well this strange Inconstancy of you,
Does prove, Alas! This Observation true,
"Excess of Merit makes the Brave to fall,
"And proves more hurtful than no Parts at all."
Well! 'tis resolv'd, nor do I care who know it,
Since Things are grown so bad, I'll turn Poet:
And like my Brother Blockheads of the Age,
In stingless Satyr vent my venom'd Rage.
It matters not how dull each thing that's said,
If I but print, I surely will be read;
Some senseless Song, (to suit the manly Tone
Of Sullivan,) which Sheridan may own,
And claim an honour envy'd him by none.
Or else, (for since I've turn'd Wit, I find
My Head to Politicks is much inclin'd)
If Lucas will admit me of his Party,
I will espouse his Cause with Rancour hearty;
Call all Men Knaves, and Jacohites to boot,
Whose Maxims don't with his own Notions suit;
And Reason's self, with Reason's Aid confute.
With indefatigable Bawling drown,
All other Voices in this noisy Town;
Till Sense, and Learning I've run fairly down.
For he who would to quick Preferment rise,
Must take some Path untrodden by the Wise;
The great Arcanum now in Madness lies.
Then since the fashion 'tis, the Town shall see,
I will write Things more crazy still than he:
Lords, Commons, Bishops, in my madding Rage,
Will I expose as Villains of the Age;
Judges and Aldermen, with Libels mawl,
Or write dull Traps to hamper Gallows-Paul.
Helvidius Priscus, is a Name will sit on
My Back as well as other's, — or Free-Briton.
But if fastidious they will not admit,
To prop their sinking Cause my stronger Wit;
(For there are Fools, and Plenty in this Town,
Who think no Nonsence current but their own)
For t'other Side then will I be a Stickler,
And write smart Essays to support the Tickler.

DIV1.HEAD: The PREFACE.
DIV1.P:
AS Prefaces are seldom look'd into, till the Book is read, I have, for the Ease of the Reader, plac'd mine at the End; which, if he be curious enough to peruse, he will find in it little more than what others usually contain; A Defence of the Work. A necessary Consolation against the ensuing Malice of some Cri∣ticks, who generally decry a Performance, with as lit∣tle Reason as the Author commends it. 'Tis in Conformity to so prudent a Rule, I here apprize my Readers, (especially such of them as are ignorant of Greek and Latin) that they will find the polite Elegance of Terence, the Wit and Humour of Plautus, the sharp Raillery of Aristophanes, and many of the unknown Excellencies of Menander, in this Piece happily united. I say nothing of the Moderns, whose Works I disdain to Copy; being of the same Opinion with many learn'd Criticks of this City, that except Colley Cibber, Far∣quhar, and two or three choice Plays of Mrs. Susannah Centlievre, the rest are not worth Reading. For certain I am, was there the least Grain of Merit in any of the others, as some positive Fools insist on; so wise and learn'd a City as Dublin, wou'd certainly e'er this have found it out. And here I cannot forbear, in the great Joy of my Heart, from congratulating my Countrymen upon the immense Treasure of Learning, and Genius they possess in the Person of the great Mr. Sheridan, a Man who not only assists our Taste in acting such Plays as are conformable thereto, but brings all others of what Texture soever to the same Level. A Shakespear in his Hands, seems no more than a Young or a Rowe wou'd in anothers. He studies our Capacities, and corrects each sublime and knotty Passage to such an intelligible Lowness, as I am sure the meanest Auditor cannot but be satisfy'd therewith. 'Tis in order to be assistant to so great a Reformer, I have by me a perfect Plan, or set of new Rules, drawn from his own Practice, for adjust∣ing the Oeconomy of Dress, the Intervention of Songs,
and Dances between the Acts, Roratorio's, Hibernian Triumphs, and Concerts of Musick, with all the Play-House Tackle, such as Thunder, Lightning, Hail, Rain, Snow, Sea Scenes, Rising Suns, and Magick Lan∣thorns. In short every Thing that ought not to belong to a Play-House, I have most carefully collected: and till such Time as a proper Season comes for publishing them, it is requested that young Gentlemen will conti∣nue to resort Smock-Alley Play-House, as the only School in which they may have their Knowledge of these Matters encreased, and a Foundation laid for that sub∣lime Way of Thinking, which no Documents, or Rules to the contrary, will ever be able to eradicate.

But to return to the Praise of my Book,—I am not so arrogant to say, 'tis the best Piece of Ridicule ever was written, but if my Reader of his own Ac∣cord is willing to think as much, truly I will not quar∣rel with him for the Matter,—for the Sake of Peace much Obstinacy must be born with, —as odd Things have been asserted before now, and if it be necessary that Criticks should mistake sometimes, they may as well mistake in my Behalf, as in any other Author's, I shall not be the first who has got an undeserved Reputation; and indeed of late Years, the publick seem to have got a Knack of praising the worst Things most, As they say indulgent Parents treat with the greatest Tenderness their weak Children, but resign to Fortune, or their own In∣dustry, those of a more vigorous Constitution.

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: SPEEDILY will be published a Comedy called the MODERN REHEARSAL, written by the Author of the ELECTION.
